Chromobacterium piscinae is a species of bacteria that was first isolated from a freshwater fish pond in Japan. It is a Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, and motile bacterium that belongs to the genus Chromobacterium.

The cells of C. piscinae are typically rod-shaped and can range in size from 0.5 to 1.5 micrometers in width and 1.5 to 3.0 micrometers in length. They are known to produce a characteristic violet-colored pigment, which is a result of the production of the secondary metabolite violacein.

Chromobacterium piscinae is considered an aerobic bacterium, meaning it requires oxygen for growth and metabolism. It is able to grow well in a variety of nutrient-rich media and can thrive in a range of temperatures, typically between 20°C and 37°C.

This species has been found to exhibit antimicrobial and cytotoxic properties, which has led to interest in its potential applications in the fields of medicine and biotechnology. Further research is ongoing to explore the ecological roles and potential uses of this unique bacterium.
